®
Major Tire Manufacturer
Comprehensive HVAC/R Capacity Study
Featuring the PermaFrost NMR® Energy Conservation Measure (ECM)

PermaFrost NMR® Eﬃciency Report
Major Tire Manufacturer
May, 2013
Executive Summary
         This report contains specific information regarding the installation of the energy control measure (ECM) 
PermaFrost NMR® in the primary HVAC split system serving the main offices at the Major Tire Manufacturer 
Manufacturing Plant located at [South Africa Manufacturing Facility Address], South Africa. Detailed forensic performance 
testing (outlined later in this report) was performed on a nominal 70-ton (246kWR) air-cooled split DX system 
using R22 refrigerant. Following testing, the unit was treated with the proper amount and type of the 
PermaFrost NMR® technology specially formulated for these types of systems. 
The improvement in efficiency and restored capacity gained directly 
at the system was solely attributable to the PermaFrost NMR® 
ECM. This is a result of the reversal of thermal inefficiency on heat exchange 
surfaces, creating greater efficiency in refrigerant approach and the 
thermal energy transfer abilities of the cooler and condenser vessels. 
Following treatment with the PermaFrost NMR® technology, the 
system showed an effective net 46.1% reduction in kW based on 
the exact capacity measured in the baseline M&V and the post 
gestation M&V. With both 35-ton (123 kWR) compressors 
operating at full load, the system showed a 15.5% reduction in 
kW, while simultaneously producing an increase in capacity of 
32.7 tons. This 57.1% increase from the baseline performance 
levels produced an effective net reduction in kW/ton of 46.1%, 
which directly correlates to what Major Tire Manufacturer will realize in energy 
savings as they operate the system in the future under the same 
parameters. Case in point, Major Tire Manufacturer has reported the system is 
now able to attain set-point temperatures in the main offices on 
most days while operating only one compressor instead of two.
Energy Science Division

Following treatment with the PermaFrost NMR® technology, the Amp draw on the system was also 
reduced by 15.6%. Simultaneously, the system showed a substantial 60.3% improvement in Enthalpy 
Delta, which is a critical HVAC measurement used to determine the thermodynamic enhancement 
brought about by the PermaFrost NMR® ECM.  The result of the ECM improvement is an ROI (Return on 
Investment) to Major Tire Manufacturer that is measured in months. The tables of data are available for review at the 
end of this report. Financial calculations determining the true ROI are proprietary to Major Tire Manufacturer under 
separate cover.  
Product Brief
         PermaFrost NMR® is a multi-patented nanotechnology surface chemistry Energy Control Measure 
(ECM) that uses Nucleo Molecular Regenerative (NMR) technology as its core agent. A sustainable, 
one-time treatment with no down time required, PermaFrost NMR® lasts for the remaining life of any 
type of system in which it is installed. Examples of the types of commercial HVACR systems and 
equipment that PermaFrost NMR® has proven success with are direct expansion air systems (DX); 
chilled water systems (both flooded and DX; air and water cooled); ice making equipment; ammonia 
refrigeration plants (single compressor and cascade) and variable refrigerant flow (VRF) designs. The 
equipment utilized in these systems within our expanding portfolio of clients includes centrifugal 
(single and multi-stage), scroll, reciprocating and screw configurations.
The direct benefits of PermaFrost NMR® are improved cooling performance, increased capacity and 
improved refrigerant velocity – all of which allow systems to achieve set point temperatures in a more 
rapid fashion which reduces compressor operating periods. The indirect benefits resulting from the 
enhanced thermodynamic characteristics following treatment include reduced run time, less kW hours 
used, less amp draw at the compressor, longer equipment life cycle time and a reduced carbon footprint 
for Major Tire Manufacturer.
Energy Science Division

Measurement and Veriﬁcation Protocol
The International Performance Measurement and Verification Protocol (IPMVP) was utilized in the 
development of this report. The Association of Energy Engineers (AEE), The American Society of Heating, 
Refrigeration and Air-Conditioning Engineers (ASHRAE), and The Efficiency Valuation Organization 
(EVO) accept the IPMVP as a global methodology for determining the effectiveness of energy conservation 
methods and products.
There are four distinct options in the IPMVP protocol for energy conservation professionals to utilize. They 
are options A, B, C and D.  Retrofit Isolation (Option B) was the option used for this report. Option B is 
defined as: All parameter measurements with the boundary of the ECM (PermaFrost NMR®) as the single 
source of measurement. Savings are determined by field measurement of the energy use of the ECM 
affected equipment or system and any performance enhancements versus the baseline data.
Measurement frequency ranges from short term to continuous, depending on the expected variations in the 
savings and the length of the reporting period. For the boundary utilized for Option B short-term 
measurements are very useful as data when the variables are contained. The savings are calculated by 
short-term measurements of baseline and energy reporting period (post), and /or engineering computations 
using measurements of proxies of energy use. 
The final computation follows the formula:
Energy Science Division
Option B savings = Baseline Energy – Reporting Period Energy
+/ - Routine Adjustments +/ - Non-Routine Adjustments

Energy Conservation Method (ECM) Content
The content within the following report will demonstrate the ability of PermaFrost NMR® to correct the 
effects of thermal degradation and fouling on the heat exchange surfaces.
 
A diagnostic examination of the pilot equipment was implemented to determine if the unit’s operational 
conditions were satisfactory.  Baseline measurements were recorded and then the proper amount and type 
of PermaFrost NMR® was injected. The gestation period for the Major Tire Manufacturer pilot was six (6) weeks. At the 
end of this gestation period, Post results were taken in the identical manner as in the baseline, taking special 
care to match the same or very similar entering air temperatures and compressor discharge pressures. These 
are the two most critical measurements affected by the weather. When analyzing the data, no adjustments 
for weather were necessary. 
The following report produces the utilization of the International Performance Measurement and 
Verification Protocol (IPMVP) as the M&V plan. The final calculations were performed by Powertron 
Global’s Forensic Mechanical Engineer, [Senior Energy Engineer], CEM/CMC/CMVP. Douglas North, 
Facilities Management Director, Major Tire Manufacturer [Eastern Cape Location] Plant, witnessed all phases of the M&V.  
The results were formulated by entering the data into the following thermodynamic engineering formulas:
 
kW = Volts * Amps * Power Factor of 1.47/1000 (for 3-Phase)   
 
BTUH = CFM X 4.5 (standard air) X Calculated Enthalpy Delta
 
kW / Ton = kW / Actual Tonnage or kWR
 
Percentage Eﬃciency = Measured BTUh / Manufacturers Design BTUh
Energy Science Division

System Description / Design Characteristics
This split system provides the primary comfort cooling to the main offices at the [Eastern Cape Location] Major Tire Manufacturer manufac-
turing plant in South Africa and runs ~6,120 hours per year according to the bin data captured from that region.
Baseline and Post Measurements
The identical IPMVP following data were recorded for Baseline and Post on 2/22/13 and 5/1/13 respectively 
using recently NIST calibrated devices to insure measurement accuracy. The Return Air entering the coil was 
identical in both periods. Additionally, the discharge pressures of the compressors in both periods were very 
similar so no adjustments were made to the calculations. The measurements are as follows:

Results
The following are the final calculated performance measurements following the PermaFrost NMR® Post 
measurement period.
Major Tire Manufacturer ROI Analysis  
Utilizing the data in the above charts, the following steps were taken to determine a very accurate ROI for 
Major Tire Manufacturer for implementing this ECM:
Baseline kW         1.24 kW/ton * 39.7 tons = 49.2 kW
Baseline Annual kWh         49.2 kW * 6,120 hours = 301,104 kWh
Baseline Annual Cost         301,104 kWh * .10 cents = $30,110
Regression Analysis is then used to account for the tonnage restored to the Split System  
Adjusted Baseline Tonnage         62.4 tons (equates to tonnage in ERP)
Adjusted kW Baseline         1.24 kW/ton * 62.4 tons = 77.4 kW
Adjusted Baseline kWh         77.4 kW * 6,120 Annual Operating Hrs = 473,688 kWh
Revised Cost to Run Baseline         473,688 kWh * $.10 = $47,369
kW Post         .67 kW/ton * 62.4 tons = 41.8 kW
Annual kWh Post         41.8 kW * 6,120 hours = 255,816 kWh
Annual Cost Post         255,816 kWh * .10 cents = $25,582

Energy Science Division
Avoided Energy Cost (savings) Per Month         ($47,369 - $25,582)/12 = $1,816
Cost of PermaFrost NMR® installed         $8,750 / $1,816 = 5 months
        ROI = 5 months
Engineering Conclusions
The client, Douglas North, Facilities Management Director, Major Tire Manufacturer [Eastern Cape Location] Plant was consulted 
regarding this equipment after the avoided energy reporting period (post analysis) and the following 
observations were discussed.
 
        The evaporator coil has some visual mold growth on the leaving airside of the aluminum fins. This is 
causing some additional pressure drop across the tube and fin evaporator.
 
 2     The blower drive components are not performing at the proper RPM due to the degradation of drive 
sheaves. Once corrected, the belts should also be replaced. This is causing a reduction in the area of available 
delivered cubic feet of supply air per minute (CFM). Please note that this condition was present during the 
baseline data period and was not corrected until after this pilot analysis was to be completed. Now that the 
pilot testing period has ended, this correction should commence.
 2     Compressor number one (1) was recently replaced and is now showing evidence of overheating. There 
is a refrigerant leak emitting from the capillary tubing connecting the compressor to its respective safety 
switches. Evidence of this refrigerant oil can be seen inside of the pressure controls section cabinet.
        There are four segregated sections of evaporator coils that are joined together creating one evaporator. 
Compressor #1 serves two of the circuits and the other two circuits are served by compressor #2. Each 
section of the respective circuits is comprised of two thermostatic expansion valves (TXV) for each 
compressor. Each of these TXV’s had a different superheat. This should be corrected in a timely manner. The 
evaporator should be cleaned and the belts and sheaves should be corrected before this adjustment is 
initiated.

Energy Science Division
        After the superheat is adjusted for each compressor, the refrigerant charge should also then be adjusted. 
The manufacturer’s suggested superheat range was not available, however a system such as this should 
operate in the 10 to 15 degree F (-12 to -9 ºC)  . Slight sweating of the rear of the compressor motor body 
should be evident as a result of a proper adjustment. Currently the superheat is above 33 degrees F (.5 ºC). 
High superheat is an indication of less than adequate refrigerant being supplied to the evaporator resulting 
in loss of cooling, dehumidification and overheating of the compressor hermetic motor and mechanical 
components.
